Lord Irwin, Governor-GeneralI1^^^^^^^ of India, made a statement to the Cabinet in regard(previous reference: to the political situation in India, at the end ofCabinet 11(29), Con- which he made certain suggestions as to procedureelusion 10.)in connection with the Report of the IndianStatutory Commission.after the Governor-GeneralTs statement the Prime Minister expressed the thanks of theCabinet, who, he said, congratulated themselves,on the fact that Lord Irwin was now Governor-General,which gave them a sense of confidence and security and a guarantee that they could put their view tohim with absolute sincerity, with the knowledge that he would reciprocate.The Cabinet favoured the proposal of theGovernor-General that at an early date there shouldbe an interchange of letters between the Chairmanof the Statutory Commission and the Prime Minister,in the course of which the latter should make clear (i) that Dominion status was the ultimate aim of the Government's policy, which they were trying to help the peoples of India to achieve by stages: (ii) that the Government intended, afterthe receipt of the Simon Commission's Report, to formulate draft proposals. These should be offered for examination by a Conference in London,-which representatives of different shades ofopinion in India would be invited to attend.(The Cabinet ad 3.0 lrned ateil.0 a.m.,and re-assembled at 2.15 p.m.) 2. The Cabinet agreed to the following arrangements for the transaction of cabinet business during the Recess:-(a) That the following Ministers, solong as they were present in London,should form a Committee to transact,on behalf of the Cabinet, suchbusiness as may arise:-The Prime Minister (who is prepared tocome from Lossiemouthif occasion requires),The Chancellor of the Exchequer,*The Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs56,The Lord Privy Seal,The Home Secretary,The Secretary of State for War,The Secretary of State for Air, ^The President of the Board of Trade ,The First Commissioner of Works:(b) All Ministers should leave theiraddresses with their Private Secre-taries and instruct the latter tocommunicate addresses to the secretary in case an emergency Meeting should become necessary:(c) The next regular Meeting of theCabinet should be held on WEDNESDAY,SEPTEMBER 25th, at 11 a.m., at10, Downing Street, unless a further communication is received:(d) That the Prime Minister (so long ashe is available), the Chancellor ofthe Exchequer, the Secretary of Statefor Dominion Affairs, and the Presidentof the Board of Trade, should assistthe Lord Privy seal in questions ofpolicy arising in connection with his forthcoming visit to Canada.Will probably be absent for some weeks in connectionwith the Conference on Reparation.cabinet procedure.Arrangementsduring the recess .(previous reference:Cabinet 30(29), Con-cluaion 11.) CONSCIENTIOUS 3. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum byOBJECTORS IN ,THE CIVIL the President of the Board of Education (PaperSERVICE.C.P.--219 (29)) in regard to Conscientious Objectorsin the Civil Service, suggesting that the Regulationof the Civil service Commission, under whichconscientious objectors are excluded from theCivil service, be rescinded, and that steps be taken in Government Departments to render conscien-tious objectors eligible for all appointments .The Cabinet agreed --That the embargo on the appoint-ment of conscientious objectors Inthe Civil Service should be removed,on the understanding that this doesnot apply to the Service Departments. land drainage .(previous reference:Cabinet 28(29), Con-elusion 9 .)1974. The Cabinet had before "them a-Memorandum bythe Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries (paper cp.-221 (29)) on the subject of Land Drainage,Cne suggestion contained in the Memorandum wasthat representatives of the Treasury, the Ministryof Health and the Ministry of Agriculture andFisheries should be asked to consider the various alternatives for overcoming the difficulties incarrying out the recommendations of the RoyalCommission on Land Drainage, 1927, occasioned bythe complete de-rating of agricultural land underthe Local Government Act, 1929, with a view to reaching agreement upon the most satisfactory solution. The main proposal in the Memorandum,,however, was that a Bill should immediately beprepared following generally the recommendationsof the Royal Commission on Land Drainage, 1927,subject to revision of the rating proposals inaccordance with the results of the above consulta-tion.The Cabinet agreed (a) That representatives of the Treasury,the Ministry of Health and theMinistry of Agriculture and fisheries should meet to consider the various alternatives for overcoming thedifficulties in carrying out therecommendations of the RoyalCommission on Land Drainage, 1927,occasioned by the complete deratingof agricultural land under the LocalGovernment Act, 19,29, with a view to reaching agreement upon the mostsatis factory solution:(b) That the Minister of Agricultureand Fisheries should have prepared a Bill following generally therecommendations of the Royal Commis-sion on Land Drainage, 1927, subjectto the revision of the rating pro-posals mentioned in(a):(c) That the Secretary of State for scotland should prepare a similar Bill for Scotland. "On behalf of His Britannic Majesty'sGovernment in the United Kingdom andsubject to ratification, I accept2.3.4.5.6."for a period of fifteen years and thereafter until such tLme as notice maybe given to terminate the acceptance,"in relation to any other Stateaccepting the same obligation,"the jurisdiction of the Court ascompulsory,"in all international disputes corn-prised in the categories mentioned inArticle 36 of the Statute"arising after the ratification ofthe present declaration, with regard to .situations or facts subsequent to the saidratification,"other than disputes in regard towhich the parties have agreed or shallagree to have recourse to some other methodof peaceful settlement,"and subject to the proviso that HisBritannic Majestyfs Government reserve the right to require that proceedings in the Court shall be suspended in respectof any dispute which has been submitted to,and is under consideration by, the Councilof the League" .It was also stated in the Cabinet Committee'sReport that the Declaration was being communicatedto the Dominions with an expression of strong hopethat, in view of the importance of unanimity inthis matter, they should concur.8 The Cabinet agreed (a) That the anno tine em ent and signature of the Optional Clause should takeplace during the next meeting of theAssembly of the League of Nations,subject to,(b) That unless the Secretary of Statefor Dominion Affairs failed to s ecurethe agreement- of the Dominions,signature should be accompanied bythe Declaration quoted above:(c) That Cabinet approval of the text ofthe Declaration should be subject tothe results of conversations between sir Cecil Hurst, the Legal Adviser tothe Foreign Office, and representa-tives of any of the Service Depart-ments that might so desire. (TheFirst Lord of the Admiralty and theSecretary of State for Air havealready expressed their desire forthis conversation.) If agreement onthe terms of the Declaration was not reached at this Conference, theSecretary of State for Foreign affairs should refer the matter to the prime minister ter. PROPOSEDPICCADILLYSUBWAY.6.The Cabinet had before them the following papers in regard to the proposed roadway andtunnel from Berkeley Square to The Mall:-A Most Secret Memorandum by theMinister of Transport (paper cp.-212 (29)) explaining that up to date approximately 20,000had been paid out of the Road fund in easements and on certain sections:of the line, and raising the ques-tion as to whether a further sum,estimated at 57 000, should be spent for acquiring the requisiteeasement for another substantialsection of the subway. If action was not now taken to protect theline of the tunnel, the possibilities-ity of constructing it at some future date would be lost, the 20,000 aLready paid would havebeen wasted, and an opportunitywould be missed for providingimportant relief to the traffic congestion in Piccadilly:AMemorandumby the First Commis-sioner of Works (Paper CP.-213(29)) criticising the scheme,more particularly on account ofits interference with the amenities of the Green Park, and containingcertain suggestions for safeguards,e.gthat the tunnel, if constructed,should be used only for the lighterkind of traffic.The Cabinet agreed (a) Not to approve the scheme referred toin the Memorandum by the Minister ofTransport (Paper 0.P.-212 (29)) orany scheme that interferes with the amenities of the Park:(b) To refer the question back to theMinister of Transport to examine whether there was any possible alternative that he could recommend. BAST -AFRICA...policy in,publicationof Sir SamuelWilson's Report(previous reference:Cabinet SO(29), Con-elusion 29 .)7. The attention of the Cabinet was drawn toan Answer that had been given in the House ofCommons on Wednesday, July 24th, 1929, by theParliamentary Under-Secretary of the Colonies tothe effect that he hoped that it would be possiblefor Sir Samuel Wilson's Report to be published earlyin September, simultaneously, in this country andin East Africa. The Cabinet were informed thatthis Answer had been given within an hour or twoof the rising of the Cabinet on July 24th and before the Conclusion of the Cabinet was known that decisions in regard to Sir Samuel Wilson\sReport were postponed pending certain enquiriesby the Secretary of State for the Colonies andthe Secretary of State for India.The Cabinet agreed (a) That Sir Samuel Wilson's report should be published, subject tosuch emendation of wording as maybe required by the Secretary ofState for India:(b) That, when published, the report should be preceded by a copy ofthe Declaration made by the lateSecretary of State for the Colonies,and confirmed by the present Govern-ment, that His Majesty's Government-is in no way committed to the views expressed in the Report:(c) That no decision on the issues'raised in the Report is implied by its publication. THE WIDOWS',ORPHANS' and old AGE CON-TRIBUTORYPENSIONS ACT,1925.proposedAmendingBill.(previous reference:Cabinet 50(29), Con-clusion 7(o) and (d) .)8.The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the Minister of Health (Paper CP.-252 (29))asking the authority of the Cabinet for thepreparation of a Bill to amend the Widows',Orphans' and Old Age Contributory Pensions Act,1925, with a view to its introduction immediatelyafter the Recess. The Memorandum also gave an indication of the main provisions of the proposed bill, and was accompanied by a Memorandum by theGovernment Actuary containing an estimate of thecost of the proposals .The Cabinet agreed "(a) That in the preparation of theBill the Minister of Health shouldhave the assistance of the Chancellorof the Exchequer and the Secretaryof state for Scotland, and that thethree Ministers should concert themost effective measure they could with the money available to carryout the policy of the Government:(b) That whenever the Bill was introducedit should be made clear that this isonly a first instalment of the Govern-ment's^policy as announced in the King'sSpeech"", and that it is hoped tointroduce armore comprehensive measure in a subsequent Session.SEThe relative passage of the Eing's speech is asfollows:-"My Ministers are engaged on a generalsurvey of the various National insurance and Pensions Schemes. Meanwhile a Billis being prepared to amend the Widows',Orphans' and Old Age Contributory pensions act, 1925, so as to modify the conditionsapplicable to certain pensions, and tomake some increase in the classes ofpersons entitled to them" . LONDON SQUARES. 9. The Cabinet were reminded that no decision(Previous had been taken at the previous Meeting in regardReference:Cabinet 30 to the Memorandum by the Minister of Health on(29) Con-clusion 7.) London Squares (Paper C.P.-227 (29)). They were informed that the Prime Minister was considering whether a measure could be introduced.The Cabinet agreed That if the introduction of a Billshould be sanctioned,(a) The question of compensation should be dealt with on thelines of the reservation madeby the Rev. A.G.Pritchard andMr Snell to the Report of theRoyal Commission, viz,:-"It appears to us that the provisions ofthe London Building Act as to generalbuilding lines, and more especially theprovisions of the Metropolitan CommonsAct, 1866, do, in effect, provide forsterilisation - a maintenance of thestatus quo - without compensation, andthat there is no reason why these enact-ments should not be regarded as providing a precedent for the non-admission of theclaim for compensation in regard to thesterilisation, or the maintenance ofthe status quo, of the existing squaresand enclosures.Our conclusions on this matter arestrengthened by the consideration that,if the claim for compensation be allowed.,not only will the danger to the preservation-tion of the squares be increased, butowners will be tempted to involve theLocal Authority in lengthy and expensivearbitration proceedings, especially inview of the complicated question ofbetterment' that would doubtless arise.The admission of the claim for compensa-tion might actually endanger the exist-ence of the squares at a time when public authorities feel unable to increase their financial commitments.We are unable to see that the maintenanceof the status quo would inflict injuryupon, or reduce the value of the propertyof, the owners of the squares......,'7'(b) The question of legal claims to compensation ation should be carefully looked into, andthat where such claims arevalid compensation should bepaid.
